Problem:
Consider the function \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t}x(t) \) acting on a complex function \( x(t) \), where \( \omega \) is a constant frequency. We examine the consequences of applying an Integral transform \( \mathcal{L} \) defined by \( \mathcal{L}\{x(t)\} = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}x(t) \, dt \) over time t.

If \( z(t) \) is applied to a function \( x_0(t) \) at t = 0, and then the Laplace Transform \( \mathcal{L} \) is applied without further intervention, will \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\} \) be the same as if \( x_0(t) \) was directly transformed under \( \mathcal{L} \)?
Explanation: The transformation via \( z(t) \) modifies \( x(t) \) by a factor \( e^{i \omega t} \), which alters the frequency components of \( x(t) \). The Laplace Transform \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\} \) thus yields a result shifted in the s-plane by \( i\omega \), compared to \( \mathcal{L}\{x(t)\} \).
